chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Other conditions that may present similarly to acute gastroenteritis include:

  • Other infective causes, including:
    • Urinary tract infection. See the CKS topics on Urinary tract infection - children, Urinary tract infection (lower) - men, and Urinary tract infection (lower) - women for more information.
    • Pyelonephritis. See the CKS topic on Pyelonephritis - acute for more information.
    • Chest infection. See the CKS topics on Cough - acute with chest signs in children and Chest infections - adult for more information.
    • Otitis media. See the CKS topic on Otitis media - acute for more information.
    • Sepsis. See the CKS topic on Sepsis for more information.
  • Other causes of diarrhoea, including:
    • Irritable bowel syndrome. See the CKS topic on Irritable bowel syndrome for more information.
    • Inflammatory bowel disease. See the CKS topics on Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis for more information.
    • Colorectal cancer. See the CKS topic on Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
    • Hirschsprung's enterocolitis. See the CKS topic on Constipation in children for more information.
    • Short bowel syndrome.
    • Food-sensitive enteropathy (such as lactose intolerance). See the CKS topic on Food allergy for a definition of food intolerance.
    • Coeliac disease. See the CKS topic on Coeliac disease for more information.
    • Toddler's diarrhoea.
    • Constipation with overflow. See the CKS topics on Constipation in children and Constipation for more information.
    • Diabetes mellitus. See the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1 and Diabetes - type 2 for more information.
    • Hyperthyroidism. See the CKS topic on Hyperthyroidism for more information.
    • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
    • Addison's disease. See the CKS topic on Addison's disease for more information.
    • Hypoparathyroidism.
    • HIV/AIDS. See the CKS topic on HIV infection and AIDS for more information.
    • Secretory tumours, for example, carcinoid tumours, medullary tumour of the thyroid, and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)-secreting adenomas.
    • Drugs, for example, antibiotics, antimalarials, magnesium-containing antacids, antimotility drugs, and laxative misuse (the condition normally reverses on withdrawal of the drug).
  • Other causes of abdominal pain, including:
    • Acute appendicitis. See the CKS topic on Appendicitis for more information.
    • Intestinal obstruction (may present with constipation, abdominal distension, abdominal pain, and vomiting).
    • Intussusception (may present with right lower quadrant tenderness, a sausage-shaped mass in the abdomen, and redcurrant jelly stool).
    • Malrotation of the midgut (may present with bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and bloody stools).
    • Biliary colic and acute cholecystitis. See the CKS topic on Cholecystitis - acute for more information.
    • Perforated peptic ulcer. See the CKS topic on Dyspepsia - proven peptic ulcer for more information.
    • Diverticulitis. See the CKS topic on Diverticular disease for more information.
    • Pancreatitis. See the CKS topic on Pancreatitis - acute for more information.
    • Testicular tortion (may present with abdominal pain and nausea or vomiting in boys). See the CKS topic on Scrotal pain and swelling for more information.
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease, salpingitis, or tubo-ovarian abscess. See the CKS topic on Pelvic inflammatory disease for more information.
    • Ectopic pregnancy. See the CKS topic on Ectopic pregnancy for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on differential diagnosis is largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Diarrhoea and vomiting caused by gastroenteritis: diagnosis, assessment, and management in children younger than 5 years [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2009], the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) publication Clinical practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of infectious diarrhea [Shane, 2017], the World Gastroenterology Organisation global guidelines Acute diarrhea in adults and children: a global perspective [Farthing, 2012], and expert opinion in a review article on acute diarrhoea in adults [Jones, 2009], on gastroenteritis in children [Hartman, 2019], and on travellers' diarrhoea [Barrett, 2016]. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
